reviewText: I was introduced to Greg the Bunny in reverse chronological order when I watched "Warren the Ape" on the otherwise-useless MTV channel in 2010 (you can see full episodes on the MTV website. That series chronicled Warren's drug, sex, and alcohol addictions rehab with Dr. Drew. Warren lacks any moral compass or compassion for other Fabricated Americans, yet he's an endearing character. When I learned that WTA was a spinoff from GTB, I then watched on Netflix these Film Parodies from the Independent Film Channel. They combine the remorseless antics of WTA with the interrupted innocence of GTB as they parody classic and cult films in short episodes of about 12 minutes each. I loved it, and you will like it even more if you are a film buff. Be sure to see WTA and the orginal GTB series (available on DVD)Greg the Bunny - The Complete Series that aired on Fox in 2002 with Eugene Levy, Seth Green, and Sarah Silverman. It's all brilliant, disrepectful, yet somehow touching, with characters like "Count Blah" who is a Bela Lugosi-style character in his twilight years, worn down from being mistaken for The Count from Sesame Street, and who has a verbal tic that makes him say "Blah" at the end of most sentences. It's hard to say which of the three series is best -- the Fox version, this IFC version, or WTA on MTV. See them all.
